Food/drink - While not cheap the food and drink was top notch and nothing is too much trouble ( - for example they smiled and quickly accommodated my wife's lunch request for a tuna sandwich without bread!). We ate at the hotel's restaurant on our final night and found the food to be very good although the service on that evening was not perfect. There is also a very chilled jazz bar for pre-dinner drinks.    Staff - all staff that we came into contact with were extremely helpful and pleasant. Indeed this is probably this factor that made our stay at La Maison Arabe so enjoyable and why we have given it 5-stars in this review.    Conclusion - Marrakech is a fantastic location for a short break from the UK and La Maison Arabe is the perfect place to base yourself. There are undoubtedly flashier places to stay in this city (both La Mamoumia and Naoura Barriiere are within a 10 minute walk of La Maison Arabe) but for a cosy yet luxurious stay I don't think you will go wrong with this hotel.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: Perhaps the best lodging experience in our lives. Very very beautiful and elegant riad/hotel. Lovely and helpful people to assist. We will return visit in May Their restaurant: best meal we had in Morocco. Elegant elegantelegant
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: 3 of the most pleasant nights spent in Marrakech where I have stayed numerous times at other hotels and resorts; my first stay at La Maison Arabe will not be my last. After busy days sightseeing and shopping coming back to the room was like coming "home". The excellent management and friendly staff always make guests feel welcome and cared for; the public rooms feel cozy and intimate the food is terrific and Rachid the bartender concocts some amazing non-alcoholic libations. Other hotels may be more extravagant and showy but La Maison Arabe provides understated elegance and comfort on every level. I look forward to a return visit.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with friends

Review_Title: A TRUE TRADITIONAL JEM IN MARRAKESH
Review_Text: We stayed at this amazing hotel for a week and having stayed in several hotels across the world in the past there is nothing I can fault about La Maison Arabe. It was clean comfortable the staff were very friendly and attentive – they have clearly been trained very well. It was wonderful waking up every day to such beauty every where you look there is details in the way of carvings the quality of the décor the lighting etc.    There is also a lovely swimming pool with a private terraced area with sunbeds for sunbathing or relaxing with complimentary towels.  The Spa is heaven and once you have had your treatment there is an area in which you can relax for as long as you want whilst listening to soothing Moroccan music.    Breakfast consits of pastries pancakes fresh fruit etc. We ate at the restaurant near the pool and I was surprised by how delicious and incredibly tasty the food was. It was really really good!! Even the club sandwich was the best I have ever had. Please note a 10% service charge will be added on top of anything extra you have at the hotel.    In terms of location its perfect: only a 10-15 minute walk into the main square or you can take a taxi for about 20-30 Dirham.    I have to say that staying at this hotel was actually one of the highlights of my trip because I felt I was getting a real taste of Morocco without even leaving the hotel! I loved everything about it and I would definitely stay there again.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled on business

Review_Text: This is my second time at La Maison Arabe - and I am sure I'll keep coming back. This time I experienced the next wing they added which makes a huge difference. They had added a swimming pool in the hotel in town so you have a choice - you can swim after walking through the medina shopping or you can spend your day at the country club a short ride away from town on their free shuttle service. Their Trois Saveurs restaurant is fabulous...you can get traditional Moroccan food (the Pidgeon pastilla is exquisite) and also thai and international dishes for those who are tired of tagine and couscous every day. One reviewer mentioned the grand marnier souffle - the lemon one with ice cream inside wasn't too shabby either! YUMMY! The Hammam is gorgeous and the services fantastic. The location is great since you are right in town and can walk from their shopping. I can't wait to go back!!
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled solo

Review_Date: Lohit K wrote a review Sep 2010
Review_Title: Beautiful spa and restaurant, good attention to detail
Review_Text: We didn't actually stay here but after using the spa and restaurant certainly wished that we had! I had the Royal Hammam and it was a lovely experience. The spa is beautifully decorated and the staff were lovely. After the hammam we had mint tea by the pool and again it was lovely. The tea came with a small selection of Morrocan biscuits that were delicious. The whole place looks exquisite. Great location as well considering its so close to the Old Square its amazing how peaceful it is. If we ever come back to Marrakech we will definitely stay here.

We had not expected to be here! I had booked the Royal Suite at nearby Riad Kniza but our reservation for five nights had got lost between their e-mail system and their hard copy desk diary.Kamal the owner/manage offered us a "standard" room/suite at no charge for the day/night of our arrival and because he was full as recompense booked us into La Maison Arab and paid room costs for half our remaining four nights stay. The suite on the first floor with terrace overlooking the pool was spacious and very comfortable. For 350Dh /night they promptly supplied a spare bed for our son who joined us later.    We ate "Moroccan" once. The food was good and service also but it was far too expensive for what it was. Including 10% charged for service our meal for three with wine was just under 1900Dh. The other restaurant by the pool was far better value. Breakfast was satisfactory without being outstanding. The freshly squeezed orange juice and grapefruit juice dispensers were so loaded with ice that the juices were heavily diluted and their true flavours lost. Eggs ordered at table were always cooked as requested. No hard cheeses were offered until requested. Coffee was full of flavour and very strong and served in insulated flasks...perfect.    Our room was serviced twice daily by courteous staff. It was a pity that our room service ordered breakfast [noted by staff the night before our very early departure] did not come as specified.    We were as above looking forward to a Riad. This is a hotel in a Medina full of riads. The authentic Moroccan experience is therefore somewhat lost. You pays your money and takes your choice. Our choice was Riad Kniza but then I didn`t pay all the money.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Title: An ideal place to stay in beautiful (and hot) Marrakech
Review_Text: After endless weeks of research including many hours spent on Tripadvisor we chose La Maison Arabe as our hotel in Marrakech as it was one of only a handful of places that offered the following things that were important to us:  1. a medina location yet with parking as we would be arriving by rental car from Casablanca and traveling with a lot of luggage  2. ideally a riad but we were looking for something larger than a 4-6 room B&B type of place  3. swimming pool (we were going in July and so were expecting it to be hot – it was!)  4. air conditioning was a must  5. restaurant at the hotel  6. ideally an elevator (we are senior citizens)  La Maison Arabe was the perfect size; it has all the warmth and personalized service of a private club combined with the benefits of a larger hotel such as a great front desk room service bar. Our room was large and beautifully decorated and had a terrace overlooking the swimming pool. The pool was much larger than what we were expecting at a riad-hotel. There were 3 flights of stairs between our room and the poolside area where breakfast was served so the elevator ended up coming in very handy. I don’t think all the rooms at the hotel are accessible by elevator so you should double-check this if it's important for you.  The staff could not have been friendlier or more professional and always seemed to be there when we wanted something. We were pleasantly surprised by the level of English spoken by the staff. I thought I’d have to dust off what remains of my high school French but it wasn’t necessary.  The food at La Maison Arabe was out of this world. The Moroccan-French menu offered many fish dishes which was great for us as neither my wife or I eat meat. The restaurant serves delicious Moroccan wines (one of the great discoveries of our trip).  I should mention that Marrakech in July was VERY hot -- you should consider this if planning a trip to Morocco.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Title: Amazing - Best Experience of the Trip
Review_Text: Having never been to Marrakech or Morocco before we were recommended to stay at La Maison Arabe by a friend who had previously stayed there.    Staying here was the best part of our trip.    The staff we extremely friendly and very helpful. Not sure why the previous review said the lady at the front desk had made fun of her.    I started a review on every aspect of the hotel but it was so full of praises that it went on and on and I feared would not be read. So I will make this short and sweet.    You will not regret staying here. Every aspect of the hotel is impeccable. From the rooms to the food to the incredible location right next to the souk and within in arms reach of all attractions.    The staff were fantastic. Every restaurant guide hotels in other parts of Morocco and experiences La Maison Arabe organised for us to do were spot on and they listened to everything we asked for and fulfilled the requests immediately.    One of the best parts of this hotel is its country club. The hotel owns another piece of land about a 10 minute drive from the hotel. They have a shuttle bus that take guests to and from the Country Club. The Country Club is the most beautiful relaxing part of the hotel. With amazing cactus gardens and a brilliant pool that you can lye by all day this is not to be missed.    We spent our mornings with private guides and drivers that the hotel organised for us to discover different parts of Marrakech they were not expensive and very good. And then the afternoons were spent by the pool at the country club where you can wine dine and just relax.    There is also a cooking school that the hotel runs which we were told by other guests was the best part of their trip. Unfortunately we ran out of time to par take and are very disappointed by that.    The Staff were fantastic. Especially the staff who work behind the front desk. Having never been to Morocco before they helped us with every aspect of our 10 day trip and even booked other accommodation for us in Fes and other Morccoan towns. Which was also outstanding.    The Spa was also terrific. I highly recommend you treat yourself to a pampering session here if time allows.    There are so many other wonderful things about this hotel like its bar and reading room that I simply do not have time to mention them all.    All I can say is you will not be disappointed one bit by your experience if you stay at this hotel. The Owner is divine and always present on site to make sure things are running smoothly.    Highly recommended I wouldn't advise staying any where else.

Review_Title: Very nice hotel ... but the woman at the desk was quite rude and made fun of me.
Review_Text: Let me start out by saying that I have never written a bad review. When something happens I usually let little things roll off my back.    Anyway we arrived at the hotel and were greeted by the doorman who was quite nice. We didn't have a reservation and so we inquired about the price at the front desk. The doorman greeted us in English (we look quite American) and so we began speaking in English at the desk. We were told the price and went upstairs to check on the room. When we came back down asked if there was a slightly cheaper room as this room was a little pricey for us. The woman at the desk let out a large exasperated sigh and went to check out the computer. She quoted another price for a small junior suite and my wife and I talked about the price for at most thirty seconds with each other. During this time the woman at the desk was acting like we were taking about half an hour. Moments later we decided to stay and were given our keys. About this time another couple came up to the desk and as we were filling out our passport information the woman at the desk started making fun of us in Darija which is the type of Arabic that is spoken in Morocco. My wife speaks Darija!!!! She was standing there acting cool making fun of the "stupid Americans" right in front of us thinking that we couldn't understand what she was saying. As we were leaving I heard her saying in French to a guest who had just walked up to the desk how cheap we were and something about being capitalist snobs. I was nothing but nice to her.    For a nicer hotel this was not the kind of service that I expected. When we got up to the room and I mention to my wife that she was making fun of us in French she said that the clerk was making fun of us in Darija. We were nothing but nice to her.    Other than that the stay was as you would expect. The pool was nice although it close early. The bed was comfortable but we could never quite get over the service.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: We recently took advantage of a “4 nights for the price of 3” promotion at La Maison Arabe and chose a Junior Suite (“Layle”) which was just perfect overlooking the hotel’s swimming pool. It was beautifully decorated with lots of closet space and a leather-panelled wall behind the bed (which was the most comfortable by far during our entire trip to Morocco).  There is a European elegance at this hotel that I was not expecting to find in Morocco. It seemed that every object has been chosen and placed with an incredible eye and taste. The salons and bar in the older wing of the hotel particularly impressed me – everything seemed so refined and luxurious but never ostentatious or overdone.  The word refined – as well as efficient – can also be used to describe the staff at La Maison Arabe. Everyone spoke a decent level of English which was not the case at the other hotels we stayed at in Morocco.  The use of the hotel’s stunning country annex swimming pool was a big and unexpected bonus. We were told it is reserved only for hotel guests which makes sense as there were only 3 other couples there both afternoons that we went.  My husband and I stayed in one evening and ate at the hotel’s international restaurant which ended up being the best meal on our entire trip. It was also the most romantic meal accompanied by excellent guitar and lute players. We lingered on long after our dessert (a delicious Grand Marnier soufflé) to keep listening to them. Just magical!
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: We stayed for 3 days in May and I cannot say enough about this hotel; a true Moroccan experience. Located in the Medina; the location was perfect.  The staff was fantastic; helpful friendly and kind. The food was wonderful as was the service.  The country club owend by the hotel was heaven; such a peaceful oasis.  Our room "Nahr" was incredible; the private rooftop terrace was the icing on the cake.  This hotel really felt like Morocco; excedded my expectations.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with friends

Review_Title: Perfect for a peaceful short break
Review_Text: My partner and I have just returned from 4 lovely days in Marrakech. We really enjoyed our stay at hotel la Maison Arabe which was conveniently located in the historical district. This boutique hotel is not too large and perfect for a peaceful short break. It has got its own restaurant where we enjoyed 2 exquisite Moroccan meals. Excellent.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: A quiet charming alleyway lined with potted trees make this hideaway a special retreat from the madness of the streets. Beautiful rooms and a spa not to be missed. The restaurant by the pool is amazing. We loved it so much that we ate there several nights! My best meals in Morocco were at this place! When you've had enough touring and shopping take the complimentary shuttle to the pool resort they have food and beverage service there that you can charge to your room. Quiet and peaceful to regroup. Be warned that if you have sensitive skin the scrub down in the hamman may be too intense for you but if you're ok with it it's a great experience followed by a full massage--heaven......wish I was there now.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with family

Review_Text: I stayed one week at La Maison Arabe with my wife and one other couple. This is the PERFECT hotel--we tried both the "old wing" as well as new rooms and both were perfect. Very comfortable with all the modern conveniences but with tons of old world charm. The food is first rate and served in beautiful surroundings. The staff could not be more hospitable-one evening they walked us across town to try a restaurant that we would have had troubles finding on our own. The Hammam is a must.  All in all one of our favorite hotels in the world
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with friends

Review_Text: Staying at this beautiful hotel in the medina of Marrakech was one of the highlights of our recent trip to Morocco. La Maison Arabe is the perfect size not too small not too big; we felt like we were staying at a private club and were treated like royalty throughout our 4 days here. The service was excellent comparable to what we experienced years ago at certain hotels in Asia. The front desk staff was particularly helpful; nothing seemed to be a problem for them and everything was done efficiently and with a smile. The hotel is full of intimate and private spaces each a bit different but all beautifully decorated and they all flowed seamlessly from one to another. Every day I would discover something new. What a feast for the eyes! The biggest surprise for us was the hotel’s country annex which is just outside the city (the front desk arranges your transportation there). There is a second large swimming pool here set in beautifully landscaped gardens. After 3 days of non-stop sightseeing and too much shopping (we had to pay excess weight on my luggage!) this was the perfect place to just unwind before our trip home. Our next trip to Morocco will be to explore the southern region beyond the Atlas Mountains (we just didn’t have enough time on this trip) and we will certainly begin and end that vacation in Marrakech at this enchanting hotel.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: I was worried that his riad may be tired as it existed and was popular 10 years ago when I was in Morocco on my honeymoon. I researched asked questions read reviews interrogated travel agents and ultimately decided to stay here for a few nights in Marrakech because the answers were really all positive and the rate for the large suite we needed (with 2 young children) was a bit better than others I considered. Unfortunately I was right to be suspicious. It is a "tired" hotel with a somewhat shabby lobby and worn carpets etc. Paying around $800 a night I expected more. I guess you just don't get much these days. Additionally the service and food at breakfast (which is included in most Moroccan hotels) was the worst we experienced in the country. It was so bad we thought about where else to run to to feed our kids in the morning just to avoid the experience even though we had already paid for it. It was a real bummer as I spent countless hours choosing our hotels. This was my biggest disappointment. Sorry Maison Arabe but it's true.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with family

Review_Text: I am an architect and I stayed at this riad for a week towards the end of January- It is in my top ten list of favorite hotels of anywhere in the world-  The decor the ambience the service- I can not say enough good things about this Riad- I am going back to Marrakech and I have to stay here again- I took many cooking classes which I highly recommend -Aziza and Mohammed made the cooking classes really fun and I learned a lot in a short amount of time-  All the staff were kind gracious helpful with any detail-  The hammam was beautiful and the experience out of this world-  I have recommended this hotel to all my friends.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled solo

Review_Text: I spent a lot of time on this website and burying myself in several guide books before our trip. There seem to be so many wonderful hotels in Marrakech; I had a very hard time choosing where to stay. We finally chose La Maison Arabe which had been unanimously recommended by my guide books . I must say that La Maison Arabe lived up to their glowing descriptions. The decor and service is elegant understated and chic. From the doors to the artwork to the gorgeous teardrop shaped lanterns to the rugs – everything seems to have been chosen with incredible taste and sense of harmony. I worked for many years in the design business and was very impressed.  Marrakech is an amazing city and should not be missed. You can easily include it on a trip to Spain as we did. The flight was only 1 ½ hours.  Back to this hotel the service and cuisine at La Maison Arabe was far superior to what we have experienced at many “5 star” establishments both on this trip and others. I enthusiastically recommend this place.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: My husband and I recently spent a week in Marrakech for New Year’s and stayed at La Maison Arabe. We really could not find fault with this hotel. Our room was in the older wing and was exquisitely decorated and had a small private terrace. The service was impeccable at a much higher level than we were expecting. Our room was freshened up at least 2-3 times a day.  The reception areas of the hotel and bar are drop-dead gorgeous (and the very friendly bartender – Rashid? – makes a mean cocktail!). The swimming pool was heated which was a big plus for us in late December. The food was outstanding; the hotel has two restaurants: a Moroccan one (I’m still remembering the braised lamb shoulder!) and a top-notch International restaurant where we ate 2 evenings.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: It was such a joy to stay at La Maison Arabe for so many reasons. Not the least because during the Christmas/New Year period this year it was pouring with rain and quite chilly in Marrakech. It was heaven to come home to glowing open fires beautiful floral arrangements fresh tangerines a welcome cup of tea or stiff martini.    In truth it is probably more boutique hotel than riad but the Moroccan detail and atmosphere is everywhere the choice of restaurants and the quality of food the free wireless internet the charm of the barmen and all the staff makes it a true stand out. Maybe in better weather those things may not have been important but during my stay I really valued those comforts and the high level of service and the variety of facilities offered in house. The atmosphere is warm and welcoming and the staff of which there are many are so unobtrusive and delightful.    It was too cool to swim but it has a beautiful pool on site and another just out of Marrakech which would be divine in the warmer weather - a great break from the madness of the medina. All age groups were staying singles couples some families and all nationalities so it was really a delightful experience.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled solo

Review_Title: Difficult to improve upon I would think
Review_Text: La Maison Arabe is one of a large number of riads that has sprung up in Marrakech over the past ten years or so. Based upon visiting a few others to eat I would say it is more "full service" than most which probably would improve further its appeal the longer the stay.    We stayed just for 3 nights on a long weekend break. We took a Standard Suite ("Shehrazade") lovely decor comfortable exceptional standards of housekeeping nice touches such as a dialy-replenished basket of dried fruits and nuts.    The riad had many public areas of great beauty and tranquility: almost too many really as it was not a busy time of the year (apparently quite quiet for a Christmas influx). There are two restaurants the "international" one where we had breakfast lunch on the first day and took the complimentary afternoon tea. We rarely saw anyone else eating there other than for breakfast.    In the main body of the hotel there was an "arabic" restuarant: this was probably the least impressive of the 3 evening meals we had in Marrakech although still very good as the general standard of food was excellent throughout our stay.    We used the baths once but a highlight was the cookery school where we cooked our own tagine lunch. The hotel's main pool is at a different location served by regular shuttles: this was set in lovely gardens though is I imagine best in warm weather (Marrkech was a little wet the weekend we were there).    Excellent service helpful reception staff I thoroughly recommend La Maison Arabe.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: This hotel is out-of-this world. It is located in the medina (old part) of Marrakech and very close to the Jema el Fna square. When we arrived we thought our driver had made a mistake as there is no grand entrance etc but once you walk through the doors and start exploring the hotel – WOW. I have rarely seen such attention to detail both in the decoration and in the service. The staff is very friendly and attentive without being overbearing. We just couldn’t believe it as the service in all the other hotels we had stayed in throughout Morocco left a lot to be desired and we thought this was just the norm for the country. We stayed in the “Noor” suite which was a jewel…it had 2 private terraces and a gorgeous bathroom done in exquisite Moroccan tiles. The medina of Marrakech can be somewhat hectic and crazy – so it was always a pleasure returning to the beautiful oasis which is this hotel. The hotel spa is incredible; we did a hammam (steam bath) followed by one of the best massages I have had in a long time. Breakfast here was the best we had in all Morocco. What wasn’t clear to us when planning our trip is that the hotel has two swimming pools – one at the hotel and another spectacular one set in a large garden property outside the city which we unfortunately left for our last day. We will highly recommend this hotel to any friends who are planning on coming to Marrakech.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: Not much I can add to previous reviews very well organised and Prof Mohammed (a trip advisor local expert) was rea\lly knowledgeable about food and indeed Morroco. We paid 500DH eachwhich given it included the excellent lunch we were instructed how to prepare and an hour or so lounging by the lovely country club pool and transport was very fair value.for the half day. I did'nt stay at the hotel which looked pleasant and the Spanish people we went in the transport to the club rated highly enough to return 3 years in a row. I preferred the decor of our more central and much cheaper Riad  but I guess more European charms may suit some better certainly the rooms will have been light as they mostly overlooked the pool. The staff throughout were helpful and pleasant.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: I booked this hotel over the internet planning to spend a total of three days in Marrakech. However before my arrival when I was still in Tangier and three days out I became ill and needed to leave Morocco for home. I called the hotel to tell them I was canceling and was told that because of the late date of notification I would have to pay for one night. This seemed reasonable though November in Morocco is low season and everywhere I went there was availability. Regardless of my attempt at courtesy this hotel charged me for three nights citing their "policy" of nonrefundability seven day prior to arrival. I guess I understand this policy from a short-term business perspective. (If I have your money it doesn't matter if I provide a service.) Maybe this is the way business is done in Morocco but I find their crassness intolerable and will not be coming back to be ripped off again.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled solo

Review_Text: i stayed there with my partner for 3 nights   very friendly staff and nice decor rooms .  we stayed in room had private terrace it was lovely ..  hotel have 2 private restaurants in Hotel and food is very nice but bit pricey payed about 1200 DH ( £100 ) for two person .  also if you like to have airport transfer you should know they going to ask you about 200 DH ( £ 18-19 ) but we payed to taxi on way back only 80 DH ( £ 7) and i m sure taxi driver asked more than normal but it was still cheaper than hotel .  also Hotel have Country Club about 15 min. way from hotel free transfer to there and i think really very nice place . very relax and nice .  hope going to help you .
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Title: An absolute MUST- Five Star All The Way
Review_Text: I just spent four nights at La Maison Arabe and had a truly wonderful experience. The hotel is situated in the heart of the Medina minutes from the central square mosque and souks. I travel a lot for work mostly staying at Four Seasons Mandarin Oriental and Ritz Carlton's and would MOST definitely recommend La Maison Arabe over any of the five star chains that are situated right outside of the Medina. You do truly get the five star experience as well as the added bonus of being right in the city.    The hotel grounds are immaculate and the staff make you feel at home immediately. The housekeepers are fantastic; they must have come in three times a day to meticulously clean our suite. Breakfast and tea everyday were superb; including the homemade yogurt which I yearn for every morning. The galettes are an added bonus. We did an afternoon cooking class which was definitely a highlight of the trip. Mohammed the instructor couldn't have been nicer. The braised lamb tagine with candied figs and walnuts was extraordinary as was the warm eggplant salad that we made to accompany it! The Spa is also very worthwhile. I had the "Royal Hammam" package that was unreal...my skin is still glistening.    I would recommend La Maison Arabe to anybody who is a looking for a unique (and top notch) Marrakechi experience.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with friends

Review_Title: Cookery cpurse at the retreat of La Maison Arabe
Review_Text: Superb setting amazing facilities and great teachers.  Mohammerd was so helpful and made the lesson so personal to answer all of our individual questions from the best spice shops to visit right down to cultural history.  He has been a great source of recipes to put our new tagine pot to the test top on our return too!  We loved the tomato rose we are arty after all!!  Thank you to all those involved in the organisation of the day.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Title: Moroccan cookery class at La Maison Arabe
Review_Text: My friends and I signed up for this Moroccan cookery class and loved it. We were driven to La Maison Arabe's beautiful country club where we had the place to ourselves. Our instructor Mohammed was excellent and easy to follow. - he even provided us with additional recipes after we'd returned from our trip. I would definitely recommend this activity to any visitor to Marrakesh.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with friends

Review_Title: A perfect stay at La Maison Arabe
Review_Text: We usually stay in larger hotels but some friends who have been many times to Morocco kept insisting that we stay at La Maison Arabe. We are so glad we listened to them! This place is unbelievable. We felt like we were staying at a luxurious private club yet with all the advantages and service of a very well run larger establishment. Our room and the hotel were beautifully decorated – we were told that everything was chosen by the owner (who it seems is an Italian aristocrat). The hotel has 2 pools: one located at the hotel in the city and another that one gets to by a shuttle. The country setting pool is spectacular and is where as it was quite hot when we were there we would spend every afternoon. We left the sightseeing and shopping (my wife went a bit crazy with the Moroccan handicrafts) for the cooler morning hours.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Date: Richard J wrote a review Oct 2009
Review_Text: We stayed for five nights at this hotel rather more than a Riad. Reasonably situated in the Medina it is a very well appointed property which has recently been extended. When one contemplates what these improvements must have cost the tarrif is very fair but this is not an economy destination. We found everything about this place spot on (not usual for me -see my other reviews). Top class reception very friendly staff and trained to a level more commensurate to 5 stars than this moderately sized establishment.  I was surprised by the previous entry criticising lunch we were out for lunch but ate twice in the restaurant for dinner which was by any standards very good and stylish cooking. Actually the hot dessert souffle was really close to brilliant!  We had one session at the cookery school which was a bit expensive but properly organised and fun. This was held at their outlying centre in the Palmeraie with pleasant gardens and an attractive swimming pool.  You are probably getting the idea I really rate this place. You are right.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Title: A modern dream of 1001 nights come true
Review_Text: To be honest - it's not cheap. But it's a bargain considering what you get: lovely people who care for you the most delicious breakfast good food in general in case you don't want to go out two pools - one in the country surrounded by a beautiful garden and one in the city which can be a life saver in hot Marrakech -  a very comfortable clean room (I could not afford the more expensive ones and heard that they are really splendidly decorated but I was perfectly fine with mine in the newer wing of the hotel) you really have the best of both worlds. That's why I call it a modern dream: You get the the service of a modern hotel but with this special oriental fairy tale flair. I would always go again.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled solo

Review_Date: Paul A wrote a review Aug 2009
Review_Title: The weekend retreat you MUST visit
Review_Text: I've never written one of these reviews before - but having just returned from La Maison Arabe i feel compelled to share our experience. We had a truly fantastic weekend (Friday to Monday). We looked at reviews before we booked and plumped for Arabe. The staff are incredibly polite and attentive and the food in the resatuarant is first class. The monkfish tagine is a must! It is perfectly situated in The Medina and good walking distance from the square etc. The short mini bus ride to visit the Country Club shouldn't be missed - we had an incredibly relaxing time at what can be best described as an oasis. Taking lunch around the beautiful swimming pool and the attention of Ahmed during the day was superb. We will definitley be returning to La Maison Arabe.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Title: The hotel and staff is terrific!
Review_Text: The hotel lobby is beautifully decorated and situated in a way that makes you feel like you're home. The lobby/check-in staff members are friendly helpful and very efficient. The lobby is also small leaving more space for interesting furniture artifacts and art work throughout the hotel. Once we were quickly checked in we discovered something special and interesting around every corner of the hotel and up and down every staircase.    The hotel is small by some standards but spacious. You can easily "get away from it all." Aside from the guest rooms there are both outdoor and indoor semi private areas. In addition the bar/lounge area is large beautifully decorated and very comfortable. The friendly and fun staff there will make sure of it. The restaurant food is terrific and the staff is warm helpful and always smiling. Take advantage of the breakfast buffet. The buffet food is fresh and some items can be made to your specifications. If eating a very healthy breakfast is important then this alternative will work well for you.    One of the concerns we had during our trip (Spain and Marrakech) concerned noise outside the hotels since we had never stayed in any of them prior to this trip. At La Maison Arabe we were within an easy walk from the Souk and otherwise on a small but somewhat busy street. We never heard outside noise in our room. We stayed in a deluxe suite (there were three adults) and we were very comfortable. We had only a few special requests and the staff was happy and quick to assisst us.    The on-site pool and the surrounding area is very clean refreshing and relaxing. I used it several times. We also spent a few hours at the off-site pool. The drive to the site is short. Once you get there there is a 100 yard walk through a nicely landscapted area and then another surprise. More to see and do and terrific service. This was another comfortable place to relax play eat drink and socialize with other guests and staff. There was no pressure from anyone to do anything! (Including from my travel partner!)    We had never been to Africa prior to this visit. Our experience in large part due to the hotel and the staff was unexpected and pure delight. We intend to visit La Maison Arabe again soon. If you choose to stay there please say hello to Mahdi Rachid and/or Brahim from Bruce Shelley and Daniel. They were especially kind and helpful to us.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with friends

Review_Title: Beautiful Hotel, Great location, Incredible Service
Review_Text: Our family had such a wonderful stay at this oasis-in-the-city. Small elegant hotel in the heart of the old town. Minutes to walk to the square the souks and all they have to offer. Great food which they seemed to serve at our convenience. But what really put this hotel over the top was the truly outstanding personal service we received. At some point in our Moroccan trip my husband contracted a bug. By the time we reached Marrakech it was clear that he needed medical attention. The hotel manager of La Maison Arabe personally escorted us to a doctor! On a Saturday morning!! Even without this extraordinary attention we can enthusiastically recommend this very special hotel.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with family

Review_Title: Do not know why this isn't ranked #1
Review_Text: This hotel was by far was the highlight of our trip to both Spain and Morocco. The attentive and friendly staff made this a very relaxing and enjoyable retreat. The decor was the best the wonderful Hammam was very serine and perfect the smells and sounds of this hotel just made us very comfortable. One special note to the best bartender (mixologist) in Morocco- Rachid. He created special drinks for us and even educated us on tea making. Mahdi the Front Desk Manager was very accomodating to all our requests. Food drink decor spa pools even the offsite resort property was a hit! I can't say enough about how positive this place is. Don't go anywhere else in Marrakesh! It's a 10 for service food and accomodations.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with friends

Review_Title: My favorite hotel in the world.
Review_Text: As a travel writer I've stayed in some great places but this one -- for so many reasons -- is my favorite. The service is friendly and generous. The hotel is full of amazing eclectic art and has wonderful nooks and crannies to sit in with a good book. The pool in the new addition is beautiful (it's rare to have a property in the medina with a decent size pool) but don't let that you dissuade you from taking a free shuttle out to the hotel's "country club." The country club has nothing to do with golf but rather is a country oasis with some of the most amazing gardens ever (rosemary hedges) and a lovely pool area and casbah.    Located on the edge of the medina shopping is convenient but the overall area isn't noisy.    Their chicken pastillas are the best ever and even non-cooks can appreciate one of their cooking workshops.    I hope I get to return some day.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled on business

Review_Text: Only had one night whats nice about this hotel is that it offers an alternative to the "pure Riads" where its little bit larger with outstanding public spaces to hang out and a restaurant which is a huge plus. EVERY DETAIL is thought through. Particularly spectacular is the choice of color schemes and night lighting that is so magical. This doesnt just happen someone has worked hard with such attention to detail. The manager went out of her way to find me to make sure that my stay was going well. Note the historic restaurant was under renovation when I visited however the restaurant by the poole is probably the most romantic beautiful setting I have seen and they had live music playing during dinner! Room was just as nice -- the turn down service litterally reorganized all of the toiletries etc so it was as if I just checked in -- some of the best I have seen.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled solo

Review_Title: A Wonderful, Charming, Luxurious Hotel - a veritable Oasis!
Review_Text: From the moment we walked through the entry door we were welcomed and treated like royalty. The first impression of the hotel is one of elegant sophistication incorporating the best elements of Moroccan. The place is stunning! As the hotel is located right in the heart of the old medina it seems to consist of a series of interconnected buildings which really add a warmth and cosy feeling as there is no expansive lobby to contend with - instead around every corner there is wonderful with art impressive antiques armchairs etc.    The bar is a delight! Very welcoming with an extensive cocktail list. The restaurant is even more impressive with food that is beautifully presented and succeeds in creating a delectable fusion of Moroccan and European tastes.    I could also not believe that there could be a such a huge swimming pool right in the heart of the medina. I understand that this has just been added after the hotel was able to acquire an adjoining property but one would never know as the addition was seamless and integrates beautifully with the rest of the hotel.    Our room was magnificent - spacious tasteful quiet and had its own balcony. I would hightly recommend this hotel and restaurant.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: This was such a luxurious hotel. Me and my husband had the time of our lives while staying here. It is such a beautiful and relaxing hotel. The best place to be when going on vacation. The setting was so wonderful with beautiful Moroccan antiques and rugs. Everything that you could possibly need while on vacation is here. Me and my husband had such a fabulous time we can't wait to go back again.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Title: The new extension made me speechless..............
Review_Text: This is my second tripin Marrakesh and my second stay in La Maison Arabe I was so surprised by new extension new rooms more restaurant and the best of is the swimming pool. The hotel location is very convenient.Close to the down twon .Very good restaurants close by and a convenient shop across the street.The price I paid for 11 nights was excellent for what we got.Will go there again
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: Entering in the Maison Arab is as if you are entering in a small paradise in Marrakesh. Beautiful service always ready to help. The hotel is beautifully decorated with antiques. Inside the hotel there is a restaurant. Although we ate in three other considered to be the best in the city the best restaurant was inside our own hotel!! I couldn't believe it. Eat for sure the soup with orange and shoulder of lamb (this was the best plate I tried in all Morocco).
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Title: Lovely hotel, in a very busy city
Review_Text: We arrived in Marrakesh after a very long and tiring drive through the Atlas Mountain...  We were greeted by a very welcoming staff at the reception and were immediately taken to our room - it was a lovely room!!!  The bed was very comfortable and big the bathroom had both a shower and bathtub and of course had all the ammenities (slippers bathrobe shampoo soap etc). We also had a small living room space and had 2 flat tvs in the room. the room also had a very nice private terrace with view on the hotel's swimming pool. Every afternoon after walking around Marrakesh all day the room service always brought us mint tea and local sweets to our terrace! it was the perfect way to finish our exhausting days!  the staff at the reception helped us with all our restaurant bookings and was always very helpful and polite.  be sure not to miss 2 things:  - the amazing food in the hotel's restaurant. seriously dont miss out on trying: the orange soup the lamb shoulder and the beef and tomato tajine. before marrakesh we spent 4 days travelling around morocco and we had our best meal in this hotel!!  - also the hotel has a second location outside the city. on our last day we got tired of shopping and walking around marrakesh so we went for a swim and lunch there. it is also the place where they have their cooking classes and their own vegetable garden.  i would definitely stay there again!!
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Title: A beautiful retreat in the centre of Marrakech
Review_Text: I booked this hotel through recommendations in a couple of guidebooks and didn't even think to check tripadvisor beforehand.    We arrived at 10am and were expecting to have to leave our bags until we could check in later. However the hotel was not very full and we were allowed to occupy our room immediately.    The room was absolutely one of the nicest I have ever stayed in and we were also given complimentary water wine and Morrocan treats - such as dates dried apricots and walnuts. The decor was beautiful and the room felt completely new.    We ended up spending the late afternoon relaxing on the terrace by the pool after tiring of haggling in the souks - what a welcome retreat! In the evening we ended up dining in the Moroccan restaurant and tried the chicken and almond pastilla which was very different and completely mouth watering (I feel hungry even writing about it!!) followed by tagine and chicken couscous all washed down with some Cuvee du President red wine - gorgeous. Oh by the way the chef gave me the recipes for the pastilla and tagine!    We had an evening flight the next day and were once again expecting to have our luggage locked away as per usual but the reception staff allowed us a very late checkout at 4pm.    We cannot find a single fault with this hotel - location is fantastic service is wonderful rooms are beautiful... bear in mind that I have seen plenty of ropey hotels through business and leisure travel and can usually find at least a couple of issues when I stay somewhere!    We have decided we would go back for a bit of a weekend retreat at some point and would recommend the hotel to anyone.    Please remember the Arabic word for thank you = shukran!
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: We arrived at La Maison Arabe at 1 AM due to a flight delay. When getting into our room we noticed it had some problems. On the following day the manager promptly upgraded us to a brand new suite (room 240) without our asking and provided the packing and moving too!! It was just perfect!!! Bright airy and tastefully decorated with all the furniture covered in soft leather. From our terrace we had a view of the pool!! On the desk we had Moroccan wine (great!!) nuts dried fruit and a large bottle of mineral water.  The staff was incredibly polite cheerful and helpful.  The riad is lovely beautifully decorated with antique Moroccan crafts full of character. Every little corner had a sitting area with lovely sofas and always a small fountain. The pool area is large and housekeeping was constantly cleaning and maintaining it.  The localization is just perfect as you could easily walk to the Koutoubia and the Djemaa el Fna Square with the colorful bazaars and souks.  We were so pleased we chose this boutique hotel to stay at in Marrakech. If we had stayed at a one of the large chain hotels we would have had to depend on taxis.  We surely will recommend this place to all our friends who intend travelling to Marrakech!!!!
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Title: La Maison Arabe, The Charming Delight
Review_Text: Our trip to Marrakesh was absolutely wonderful! Our experience at La Maison Arabe was first class all the way. LMA is located inside the Medina walls about three city blocks from the Souk. Upon arriving I was a little surprised at the lack of a fancy entrance off the street. The entrance was midway between two streets down a cobblestone alley too small for a car. Our tour guide (from Olive Branch Tours whom we grew very fond of) was quick to point out that this is part of the magic of Marrakech you never know what lies behind the walls. The second we walked into LMA we knew we had found a hidden treasure. The people were warm and sophisticated. The furnishings of the hotel are beautiful including berber and persian rugs throughout antiques interesting ceramics and pottery old baskets and original fine art. LMA is decorated with exquisite taste to the Moroccan style and culture. There were also several darling outside courtyards complete with trickling fountains flowering vines chirping birds and butterflies. LMA has a wonderful heated pool that is large enought to swim laps. Spa services are available and I hear the massuese there is great. Free Internet and Wifi access that worked well.    I have to mention the staff at LMA. There are at least 50 employees working at all times. This is a very good guest to staff ratio unlike some of the newer Riads in Marrakech. Check this out as I heard some scary stories from some other travelers about their Riads. Some of the Riads have 3 - 5 employees that all leave after breakfast is over. At LMA everything you needed was at your fingertips within minutes presented with a genuine smile. The front desk staff was helpful knowledgable courteous and available for recommendations directions or just a friendly hello.    LMA has two restaurants and a lounge. One restaurant offered only Morrocan for fine dining and the other offered French Thai and Moroccan. People came from hotels all around Marrakech to dine here as the food wine list and service were so good. In the evenings each dining room had live musicians that just capped off the atmosphere. The Tangine Lamb L'Orange was delicious. The souflees melted in your mouth. Prices were reasonable.    Regarding our room; we had a small suite that was perfect for our family of three. The main area of the room had the master bed (mattresses were fine) spacious bath two large closets and a TV. The sitting room was complete with a couch fireplace writing desk and a single bed perfect for a third person child or adult. Everyone had privacy and we were very comfortable and made ourselves right at home.    I went to the cooking school which was located at the LMA Country Club about 20 minutes away from the main hotel. The instructor spoke French English and Arabic so there were no communication problems. We made Chicken Tagine and then sat down together and enjoyed lunch by the pool. The Country Club was very nice and could accomodate large groups. There was a great vegatable and flower garden ponds with frogs turtles and fish palm trees a restaurant and a large pool with showers. One of the other students described LMA as "palacial" and was very tempted to move there from her western hotel in new part of Marrakesh. The pictures of LMA on the website do not do it justice the hotel is much nicer.    Our stay at La Maison Arabe was fabulous; a perfect 5 on the Tripadvisor scale. My husband and I cannot fathom why it is listed as #51 and not in the top 10 if not #1. I highly recommend LMA to anyone desiring a taste of the true Moroccan culture and the comforts of a 5 star hotel. One last recommendation would be to hire a guide it was well worth it. Have fun in Marrakesh we sure did!
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with family

Review_Text: We did not actually stay at La Maison Arabe. We were staying nearby and booked a cooking class through La Maison Arabe. The class was great held offsite at a great resort location. We met someone who was staying at LMA at the cooking class and she recommended the spa there. We arrived at the hotel a half hour before our spa appointment time and had not had lunch. Starving we asked if there was somewhere in the hotel to get a snack. We were whisked off to the restaurant a beautiful table was laid and we were brought a delicious club sandwich we ordered off the room service menu as they were between lunch and dinner service. All in time to make our appointment. The spa is an amazing experience also so relaxing and restorative after a dusty day of shopping. We stayed to meet our new friend in the bar and ended up staying for a light dinner in the bar. Service at LMA was perfect throughout and we wished we had stayed there!
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Date: Susan L wrote a review Jan 2009
Review_Text: Our party were staying in the Riad Les Yeux Bleus in the adjoining street. We came across the hotel by accident and ended up eating there 6 times during a one week stay. The hotel is wonderfully decorated and the staff are imaculately turned out very friendly and helpful.    The Moroccan restaurant was excellent with plenty of choice on the set three course menu. We also ate in the International which was having some staff problems. The Director of the hotel was very apologetic and gave us free water wine and cognacs. More than enough compensation but on seeing us again the next evening gave us a round of drinks in the bar. This was not necessary but left a warm feeling with us all. We would definitely stay at this hotel should we return to Marrakech.

Review_Title: Nice - but too expensive for what it is
Review_Text: Nice very relaxing place with style and luxury.    Location is within the medina but rather on the outside.    Good restaurants (1x international 1x local)    Nice room/bathroom TV only English and French.    Service a bit too slow and unflexible.    At that price you can expect better service!

This is a wonderful peaceful hotel tucked away from the hustle of Marrakech. Centrally located you can head out to Djemaa or the souks easily or simply choose to relax and unwind in the hotel.    The 'Country Club' which contains pool gardens and restaurant is a real treat - much nicer than the website pics suggest. It is a 20 min shuttle away (probably the only slight negative to this hotel) but it is well worth an afternoon there.    We warmly recommend La Maison Arabe.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: I went to Marrakech with a girlfriend and we originally planned to stay in Riad we had booked online.  We arrived on a Monday night to our Riad quite late and it was horrible. We droppe dour bags and walked around the Medina stopping in at La Maison Arabe for dinner. On our way in we asked if there were any rooms available and the concierge said they had a room for 200 Euros. We are students and I immediatley said 200 Euros was too much at which point he countered with 100 Euros a night. He explained that the room was normally 400 Euros but that it was low season and they were trying to fill the hotel.  They showed us the Aladdin room which we were thrilled about. We put a deposit down of 100 Euros to hold the room and we returned the next morning.  The hotel had free internet on a communal computer which was perfectly doable.  The room we got the Aladdin room was great. It was big- it had two twin beds pushed together that formed one bed it had a sitting area with two chairs and a table that had a bottle of red Moroccan wine and a basket of snacks (dried fruit and nuts). It also had a small balcony with an umbrella and two sofa chairs. The bathroom was big with two sinks and a bath/shower and toilet/bidet.  The room was quite clean- We certainly had no complaints after where we had booked the night before. There was satellite TV which was OK- kinda wierd channels from different countries.  Included in the room rate was breakfast and afternoon tea- both of which were DELICIOUS. Breakfast was some croissants and pastries with homemade jam fresh OJ house made yogurt mint tea or coffee and Moroccan pancake type things.  Afternoon tea was mint tea with a plate of little cookies- a perfect afternoon pick me up.  We ate dinner in the hotel one night- it was very expensive but quite delicious. And really nice to not have to leave the hotel. We did not do the cooking class- it seemed like a lot of money.  We ate really well at other restaurants for a lot less though.  WE did do the Hammam in the hotel which was not very good. It seemed expensive for a lot of lying down and just being rubbed- which we could have done ourselves. Upon check out we mentioned our disappointment and the staff was super nice and took the tip off the bill.  We did try and do some things- like camel rides- through our hotel but we felt that in many instances teh staff had deals going with certain tour guides that would make it cost more etc. so we ended up doing most things on our own. However they did try their best to help us.  The room was tidied twice a day and the staff was incredibly helpful especially in the evenings always trying to accomodate our requests.  I woudl definitely go back to this hotel especially for its location. It is a 5 minute walk from the Djemma El Fnaa and the souks. We walked ALL over and found this to be a great location. It is far from the Nouvelle Ville but to be honest we felt there was not a whole lot going on there (beyond Ex-pats psuedo partying) that we wanted to be involved in. WE much preferred the authenticity of the Medina and we felt it was a great respite to be able to walk out of the bustle straight to our hotel. There was some construction going on next to the hotel but it was not disruptive.  Also be sure to do a caleche ride around the Medina at night when it has cooled down. Super nice.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with friends

Review_Text: La maison arabe is really one of the most beautiful riads i ever seen in marrakech we were very happy among a cheerful staffi would like to thank them for the exeptional service and splendid surroundings.

My husband and I took part in the cookery lesson held here and were delighted that we had. I am now recommending it as a 'must do tour' to another group of 20 people who are going out to Marrakech later in the year. It was both informative and fun and the end result (which we ate entirely) was delicious! Wonderfully serene surroundings and friendly people - it was a great day.

Learning to cook chicken tagine at Maison arabe was one of the highlights of my stay in Marakech- a must do! The food that we cooked was delicious and we were helped every step of the way. It was brilliant to learn about the different spices and herbs used in moroccan cooking and to talk to Mohammed about moroccan culture in general. The ladies who helped us were lovely and will show you the most impressive way to cut an onion! Also the place itself is beautiful- be sure to take your swim suit and make use of their pool surrounded by idyllic gardens. A wonderful wonderful morning!

We spent four nights at the Maison Arabe and loved every minute of it. The property is hidden away and it is a jewel. It is beautifully decorated and restored. It is located just a few minutes walk from the main square.    Our room was spacious and comfortable and gave onto a lovely terrace in the middle of which was a beautiful small marble fountain (typical in riads). I loved the bathroom with its vaulted ceilings and blue and yellow tiles.    The service was impeccable friendly and superbly helpful. We also had a hammam treatment. I had the royal treatment which was nice but I wouldn't do it again - it just wasn't worth the extra cash because all they do is smear you with extra goo. Next time I would just have the hammam treatment the scrub down and the relaxing massage.    The food at the hotel was absolutely delicious -- it's the best in town. The Moroccan pancackes prepared fresh in front of you for breakfast were scrumptious and we'll miss them - make sure you try the mixed cheese and vegetable ones. So good. Their mint tea is also the best we had during our sojourn. We also had lunch and dinner there and they were both fantastic.    Only thing - be prepared to hear the call of the muezzin very early in the morning but I think that would be the case wherever one stays in town.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: This riad is in medina close enough but at the same time far enough from souks and Jemaa el Fna. You can get by taxi 50 meters away and you walk to Jemaa el Fna in 15 minutes. Really cosy place more a palace than a hotel. Ali Baba suite with a balcony is magnificient. Breakfast was delicious but for a dinner there are better places in the city for example Tobsil. Service was friendly.    La Maison Arabe is really something to recommend for a stay in Marrakesh!
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Date: Sally Betterton wrote a review Feb 2008
Review_Text: We came here for the cookery school and liked it so much we booked out of our first hotel and into the top suite! This is such a lovely place. It was very relaxing and only a 10 minute walk to the main square. The three story suite was very comfortable. The roof terrace had a jacuzzi and their was a bathroom on the first floor as well as the ground floor. The service was excellent. The staff were very helpful and the breakfasts were very french! lovely soft french bread croissants pain au chocolat morroccan pancakes freshly squeezed orange juice coffee and homemade yogurt. Their is afternoon tea included in the B & B price. The restaurant is stunning and even though one night there was only two tables taken they still put on local entertainment.

We have stayed in both a Deluxe Room (2000 to 2.500 DHS) and a Junior Suite (3500 to 4000 DHS). Both of the rooms were disappointingly small especially for the price paid. The bed in our Junior Suite was actually two double beds pushed together so not very comfortable because neither one of us wanted to lay on the dividing line part.    The rooms were clean (and surprisingly small) and they do a good job tending to the rooms on a regular basis including turning the sheets at night. In other words La Maison Arabe is really a hotel.    The meals were also well prepared and service of high quality. Nice wait staff.    The receptionists and managers however are not completely service focused. Their quotes for guides and taxis vary from time to time which is disturbing given that it is a hotel and all of the drivers they use are probably friends or relatives. Instead of focusing on the business of making money whether for the hotel or themselves they should focus on satisfying the customers which is actually the key to making more money. Anyway we didn't really find anyone in the front desk to be overly genuine.    During our travels in Morocco I can safely say without any hesitation that Riad Kniza (in Marrakech and truly a Riad though the dinners there are not great) and La Maison Bleue (Fez) are significantly nicer than La Maison Arabe and also for less the price. In other words this neutral rating/average is relative to other options in Marrakech and not an absolute rating for this hotel. If the room rates were reduced by half they may be worth it.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Title: Very posh hotel and fun cooking class for beginners
Review_Text: This was a very nice hotel - they upgraded our room and we spent the day at taking a fun cooking class. It was pretty basic and would not be good for serious cooks but nice for beginners. Do not get a message - they were over priced and oily. The food is excellent and the service good. Nice overall - but not in the medina. About a 10 minute walk out of town.

Review_Title: Hate to Say It, But Was Slightly Disappointed
Review_Text: First let me put a caveat on the title... We had just come from a marvelous dar in Fez (Dar Seffarine) so we were open to be biased against a more-hotel-than-dar-or-riad. I think La Maison Arabe then is a partial victim of circumstance. But just partially.    The walk up to the property is lovely - down a side street moving away from the hecticness that is Marrakech. We were received by the front desk and quickly checked in. My only complaint would be our confirmed reservation for a cooking class the next day was not on their calendar. However this was easily rectified. (Side note: I strongly recommend the cooking course available through La Maison Arabe. See separate reviews.)    Our room "Soulayman" was fine but seemed a bit of a let down from the expectations set by the photos on the website. It just did not seem as charming in person. The decor felt more like a standard hotel with a few very subtle Moroccan touches to it. And at MAD 2'200 per night (roughly EUR 195) I felt a bit soaked. I regretted having opted for the junior room and wished I had saved the few extra dirham and just booked a standard room. Or instead booked a riad or a dar to exploit an opportunity unique to Morocco rather than staying in a room that felt like "just another hotel".    But where La Maison Arabe begins to separate itself from a dar or riad is the size of the property. Given that it was created from several adjoining houses there are many nooks and crannies to explore - or to sit and have a drink. The buildings are beautifully maintained. The inner courtyard is peaceful and lovely. But you could of course take advantage of these whether or not you were a paid guest. Score another one for staying somewhere else.    The one unique element that would be open only to guests (or attendants of the cooking course) is access to their offsite property via a free shuttle to and from La Maison. It is simply gorgeous. The gardens are beautifully maintained the pool (although untested by us) looked like a lovely place to quietly waste away the hours on a hot Moroccan day. Full bar service and limited meals are available.    Breakfasts were nice and offered a selection of breads pastries fresh yogurt and local delicacies. And if you wanted to completely cop out they even had several cereals on offer. All in all a good offering.    We ate at their Moroccan restaurant (there is an international menu on offer at their other) and like the property itself found it be a little overpriced. The atmosphere was great the food and service were fine but the price paid of MAD 400 per person for a three-course meal (not including beverages) just seemed high given that the quality and composition of the menu was just not that distinctive.    So to tie this all up I would say that there is nothing wrong with La Maison Arabe. Far from it. I just don't think that it is the best experience for Marrakech and certainly not one worth the price paid. For that I can only score the property as 4 out of 5.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Title: Fantastic respite from the mayhem of Marrakesh
Review_Text: We loved staying at this hotel! As mentioned in other reviews it's not quite a riad but still very intimate and "moroccan". The hotel was built from several joined buildings and has some fantastic public spaces a cozy bar a beautiful outdoor courtyard perfect for breakfast and lovely smaller courtyards and patios. The rooms are comfortable although admittedly not as superbly decorated as the other parts of the hotel. The location is great -- about a 10 minute walk to the Jemma el Fna and near the souks. We felt comfortable walking around the hotel late at night and unlike some of the other hotels in the Medina this one is accessible by car so you don't have to carry your luggage by hand.    Also a highlight of the stay is the amazing complimentary breakfast and really good restaurant. Definitely eat at least one of your meals in Marrakesh here -- it was some of the best food we had in Morocco!

Review_Title: Lovely - hotel with charm of a riad (but it IS a hotel)
Review_Text: Very pretty and elegant. Great staff. Delicious food.    Has the prettiness of a riad but does have the atmosphere of a hotel (a shop a bar etc)- ideal for pampering stay. Pool pretty but right next to where people eat so not very relaxing!    Good location.    Spa was hopeless though don't waste your money. Treatments overpriced and substandard.

I was pretty concerned about staying in a Raid as I was used to 5 star luxury. Although this was not quite the five star hotel it was a delight.    It was quant luxury and after the hustle and bustle of life outside the Riad it was a haven of peace and tranquillity.    It was superbly decorated and the room was more than adequate.    The service was excellent and the cocktails and food were great.    I would certainly recommend someone stays in this Riad even if like me they are used to 5 star .. it must be experienced.

The Maison Arabe is truely understated elegance. We stayed in the 3 story suite with our 2 teenage boys - roof top patio was to die for. The whole place exudes charm. I would stay here again and again.  The pictures don not do it justice. Service was excellent also. My one son had a bit of an upset stomache and they made a nice tyme tea infusion - good as new!!!  The pool compound is also a nice retreat though we were really not there long enough to fully enjoy it.  I would only say that there is better local food nearby than in the restaurant for dinner.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with family

Review_Text: This hotel is truly lovely charming and a nice place to stay in Marrakesh. However be very careful to specify exactly what you want for your accomodations. All the rooms are different and are in three connected buildings. My husband and I were traveling with our two sons and a very close single friend. The hotel knew this. Unfortunately when we arrived after a long drive through the Atlas mountains for a four night stay we found our sons in a room on the top floor of one building we were in a room on the top floor of another building and our friend was in the third building. They knew we were traveling with children but they separated us. Also we were supposed to have a suite and there was not one available. There was not much they could do until two nights later due to our arrival on a weekend. We were very unhappy especially as one son was ill. Also I think Americans will much prefer suites if they stay in this hotel as the rooms can be quite small. I recommend that if you choose to stay here that you invest in a telephone call and get very specific about rooms when making your reservation. There is no pool at the property however there is a truly beautiful villa and pool owned by the hotel which provides scheduled transport.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with family

Review_Text: We choose this hotel as it's in the heart of the medina and have a nice pool with a huge garden    The service is perfect the staff just nice    The food is excelent    We were very happy with the airconditionnong as it's was very hot at this time    For sure we will come again and recommend this place highly
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled solo

Review_Title: Absolutely LOVED this hotel - it's an oasis on earth!
Review_Text: This hotel is what Marrakesh is all about - traditional arab decor with the top of the line service beauty and tranquility that you can get. I could have stayed here for a month without leaving. I stayed three nights in one of the royal suites and it was worth every dollar. Three levels a private sun deck with a garden and three jacuzzis. the room had huge morroccan style windows that opened onto a tranquil courtyard where birds chirped all day - it was paradise.    The hotel sitting area is quite lovely and the staff are super friendly and speak either english or french.    The hotel provided a babysitter one night and it cost about $8 an hour. The babysitter was one of the chambermaids and she was lovely with my 9 month old son.    I would highly recommend this hotel - it was the highlight of my entire trip. It's inside the Medina and walking distance to the souks restaurants and easy to find a taxi.    If I return to Marrakesh - I will ONLY stay at this hotel

Amazing riad right in the medina of Marrakech. If you are visiting Marrakech I would only recommend that you stay in a riad. If you stay in a hotel you will miss out on the charm of Morocco. Furthermore if you want excellent service in a beautiful setting stay at La Maison Arabe.    The staff is so warm and friendly constantly seeing to your needs whether it be mint tea breakfast or a restaurant recommendation. You will want for nothing.    The rooms are all unique filled with Moroccan treasures textiles and flowers. The pool is 15 minutes away but do not be alarmed it is an enchanting garden right outside of the Medina--they operate their own complimentary shuttle back and forth. It is like having two properties in one. You can even take a cooking class in the building by the pool. It is a nice relaxing place to unwind after endlessly wandering through the medina.    You will love this place!

This is a great hotel. One big advantage is that it is easy to find. We stayed at another riad in a residential neighborhood that was in a more peaceful area but easy to get lost; and getting lost in the medina is not a fun experience when you are ready to get back to your hotel. Its about a 8 min walk to the Fna of which you dont want to stay in the craziness of the Fna. The beds were our most comfortable in morocco so far; out of 3 hotels. We stayed at all 5 star properties but it seems as if hard mattresses are preferred here. If you like soft; this is a good option. This hotel has more of a hotel feel to a riad feel to it. I think in morocco; its best to stay in at least 1 riad. There are also more rooms here than a small riad where you may not see other guests very often. At night this hotel is much more charming than when we arrived during the day. I recommend this hotel to older guests since its not a happening place or very hip. There is always someone here that speaks english which is less common at the smaller riads which simplifies the planning process if you dont speak French. Hotel has wifi but it doesnt work in most rooms so you must take your computer to the common areas. An advantage of staying here is that all taxi drivers should know of this hotel.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Title: My favorite hotle in the world
Review_Text: My parner and I stayed here in 2001 during renovations of La Mamounia and it was the best decision we've ever made in booking a hotel room (we will never go back to La Mamounia again). We enjoyed our stay so much we went back last summer with the entire family. I lived in Morocco during the late 1980's and if you had only one hotel to stay in Morocco this hotel is the very best the country has to offer. The rooms are beautiful and spotless--with the smell of dry cyprus wood and roses. The staff is knowledgable and helpful. Truly a taste of Morocco!

We have just spent 3 nights at the Maison Arabe. The hotel was excellent. Our room was lovely and well presented. The hotel itself was beautifully furnished and the staff very welcoming.  After busy days out exploring Marrakesh the hotel was a welcome retreat from all the hustle and bustle outside.  We enjoyed drinks in the bar and in the little courtyards around the hotel. The food was v good in the Morroccan restaurant but if you are "tangined" and "cous coused" out the food in the bar is good too.  It is about a 10min walk to the main square and easy to pick up taxis if you are going further. My husband enjoyed the massage in hotels hamman. Would love to have tried the Cookery School but just ran out of time.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Date: Tracy P wrote a review Jan 2007
Review_Text: We stayed at this beautiful riad for four nights in November and can't recommend it enough to anyone who is contemplating visiting Marrakech. It was our first visit to Morocco so we were a little dubious as to what one should expect but we were very pleasantly surprised when we stepped through the door into what one would describe as a tranquil oasis beautifully appointed throughout and greeted by staff who were very welcoming their English was perfect and they could not do enough for you. Our first night was spent in the Dalila which had a lovely long private balcony overlooking a small courtyard and the remainder of the stay was spent in the Chehrayar which again had its own private terrace. Breakfast was served either in the open courtyard or within one of the lavishly decorated rooms off and evening drinks were served either under the stars in the courtyard or in a very luxurious Club Bar which was run by a very knowledgable and good humoured head barman who had a wicked sense of humour and concocted the most wonderful and lethal cocktail for me so scrummy that I just had to indulge in another! We ate at a couple of highly regarded restaurants in Marrakech a couple of evenings which were excellent but our last night was spent at La Maison Arabe and what a splendid way to end our stay there. The ambience of the restaurant with its roaring fire crackling away in the grate combined with the musician and probably the best tajine I had tasted Lemon Tart to die for and a rather nice bottle of Moroccan wine made us wish we had eaten in the restaurant more. Last but not least the manager Nabila was the perfect host along with the rest of the staff and we really were quite sad to leave but I have been promised by my husband that he will be taking me back and I shall be holding him to that promise!
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: My husband and I stayed at the La Maison Arabe for 6 nights. The hotel is beautifully furnished with a mixture of European chic and Moroccon-inspired architecture and furnishings.
